00001 /** \file  mylib.h
00002         \brief generic header file that loads utilities 
00003                 often needed by programmers
00004 
00005 The header files included here are basic C library headers
00006 (such as string.h). 
00007 The other entries are declarations of functions that are expected
00008 to be commonly used by programmers using the library.  For example,
00009 functions for opening files and writing error messages are declared
00010 in this file.  
00011 */
00012 #if !defined(GLYLIB_HEAD)
00013 #define GLYLIB_HEAD
00014 /** 
00015 Some libraries that are often needed 
00016 */
00017 #include <stdio.h>
00018 #include <stdlib.h>
00019 #include <stddef.h>
00020 #include <string.h>
00021 #include <ctype.h>
00022 #include <math.h>

00024 #include <malloc.h>
00025 #include <general.h>
00026

00028 Defines that are often needed
00029 */
00030 #define _GNU_SOURCE
00031 
00032 /** 
00033 Some general-use functions 
00034 */
00035 /** Prints usage.*/
00036 void  myusage(const char *USAGE); ///< Prints usage message and exits(1).
00037 /** Prints error message and exits(1). 
00038 Prints the following: 
00039 
00040 "This program encountered the following error and will exit:
00041 
00042         whinetext " 
00043 */
00044 void  mywhine(const char *whinetext); ///< Prints error message and exits(1).
00045 /** Prints usage and an error message and exits(1). See mywhine for more information.
00046  Prints a usage statement after the whinetext*/
00047 void  mywhineusage(const char *whinetext,const char *USAGE);///< Prints error message and usage and exits(1).
00048 /** \defgroup FILE_UTILS "File Utilities" */
00049 /** \addtogroup FILE_UTILS */
00050 /*@{*/
00051 /** Opens a file with error checking. 
00052 This function will open a file and then check to see if the file actually opened.  
00053 If not, it will write a descriptive error message and exit(1) the program. 
00054 Doing this saves many, many core dumps. */
00055 FILE *myfopen(const char* Name,const char* option);///< Opens a file with error checking.
00056 /** Like myfopen, but the freopen version. */
00057 FILE *myfreopen(const char* Name,const char*,FILE* option); ///< Like myfopen, but the freopen version.
00058 /** Complains (EEK!!!) if a file read fails.  Prints the following: "
00059 
00060 Unexpected surprise during read of file FileDesc.
00061 
00062 Exiting.
00063 
00064 "*/
00065 void  read_eek(const char *surprise, const char *FileDesc); ///< Complains (EEK!!!) if a file read fails.
00066  /** Complains (EEK!!!) if a file read fails. Prints the following: "
00067 
00068 " */
00069 void read_neek(const char *surprise,int line,int field); ///< Complains (EEK!!!) if a file read fails.
00070 /** Complains (EEK!!!) if a file read fails. */
00071 void read_fneek(const char *surprise, int line, int field, const char *FILENAME); ///< Complains (EEK!!!) if a file read fails.
00072 /*! Makes certain that the number of snapshots read from a crd file makes
00073 sense in terms of the given topology file.  This declaration should be moved to
00074 some other location eventually (not so general -- really just amber). */
00075 int   crdsnaps(const char *, const char *, int);///< counts snapshots in a crd file
00076 /** 
00077 * Usage:
00078 
00079 *      const char * mylocaltimestring,mytime(format)
00080 
00081 *              -for example:
00082 
00083 *      strcpy(mylocaltimestring,mytime("format"));
00084 
00085 * where:
00086 
00087 *      format is one of:
00088 
00089 *              [keyword]       [example]
00090 
00091 *              YYYYMMDD        20070321
00092 
00093 *              YYYYMMDDhhmmss  20070321152110
00094 
00095 *              pretty          Wed, 21 March, 2007
00096 
00097 *              longpretty      15:12:10, Wed, 21 March, 2007
00098 */
00099 const char * mytime(const char*); ///< Gets the time in a nice format
00100 /*! Returns the number of times the string str is found in file F */
00101 int sscan_file(FILE* F,const char* str); ///< Scans a file for instances of a string.
00102 /*! Returns the number of times the character c is found in file F */
00103 int cscan_file(FILE* F,char c); ///< Scans a file for instances of a character.
00104 fileslurp slurp_file(fileset F); ///< Slurps in the contents of an entire file
